H0.text: Radiation is the mechanism by which the metal pot transfers heat to the water when the student puts the pot on the stove to boil the water.

H1.text: Insulation is the medium through which the metal pot transferred heat to the water when a student put it on the stove to boil the water.

H2.text: Convection is the mode of heat transfer by which the metal pot transfers heat to the water when the student puts it on the stove to boil the water.

H3.text: Conduction is the method by which the studentâ€™s metal pot placed on the stove transfers heat to the water to bring it to boil.

A4.text: heat must have travelled through the metal of the grate, by what is termed conduction.

A5.text: in this case a portion of the air, passing through and near the fire, has become heated, and has carried up the chimney the temperature acquired from the fire.

A6.text: Heat transferred between the electric burner of a stove and the bottom of a pan is transferred by conduction.

A7.text: Conduction is the main mode of heat transfer for solid materials because the strong inter-molecular forces allow the vibrations of particles to be easily transmitted, in comparison to liquids and gases.
